item.title: C question
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Maybe you’re not supposed to add the printf at all. The function getchar() is supposed to only return EOF if an error occurs or if the end of the stream is reached. An error is unlikely to occur, and you are reading from the console, so there is no real End of File (EOF). Is is indeed a crappy example if I am right, but, I think that the loop is likely to loop forever.

If you want a different behaviour, post what you want to achieve and we can see. But, that code simply waits for EOF, and, if you don’t put the printf into the loop, you will only get the number of characters after the EOF is found.

Edit: Unrelated Note: If you can choose, you should probably learn C++ at the same time.

item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Well, I’m fooling around a bit with C using The C Programming Language 2nd edition. It had this code in it: (Don’t mind the formatting)

[code]#include <stdio.h>
/* count characters in input; 1st version */
main()
{
long nc;
nc = 0;

while (getchar() != EOF)
++nc;

printf("%ld\n", nc);
}
[/code]

But it doesn’t work. It prints nothing while it’s supposed to print the amount of characters I type. When I add printf("%ld\n", nc); to the while loop it semi works. When I type 4 characters, it outputs 12345. What am I doing wrong here? It comes from a book that is claimed to be the bible of C, so I expect it to work.
